description:
Bhargavaea beijingensis is a species of bacteria that was first isolated from soil samples collected in Beijing, China. It belongs to the phylum Firmicutes and the genus Bhargavaea, which was named after the Indian microbiologist Bhargavi Dhareshwar.

Bhargavaea beijingensis is a Gram-positive, spore-forming, and aerobic bacterium. It is capable of growing at a wide range of temperatures, from 10°C to 45°C, with an optimal growth temperature around 30°C. The cells of B. beijingensis are rod-shaped and measure approximately 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 1.2-3.0 μm in length.

Phylogenetic analysis based on the 16S rRNA gene sequence has shown that B. beijingensis is closely related to other members of the genus Bhargavaea, which are known to be found in various environmental samples, such as soil, sediment, and wastewater.

The genome of B. beijingensis has been sequenced, providing insights into its metabolic capabilities and potential ecological roles. Further research is needed to fully understand the diversity, distribution, and functional significance of this bacterial species in its natural environments.
